author: rockchicella

description.text: While the flexibility of my previous design for sliding plaques is nice, it turns out that what I really need is solidity more than flexibility. Particularly since ABS gets brittle in the cold and can snap off. So I redesigned these to use my dualstrusion printer capabilities (instead of the "print in one color, stop the print, switch filament, resume" fake dualstrusion I used last time since my printer then didn't have dualstrusion), and made them shorter vertically, so they won't have anything hanging below the 2x4 to which they're affixed. That way, once affixed, they're less likely to be broken off, like some of the old ones were this winter.
The original tie by HUYA was far too short, so I duplicated elements and lengthened the tie to 19 inches.

author: marasco

description.text:
Just Another Spool Roller - Mark II

This is my second and improved version of my Spool-Roller.

Because of differend sizes and diameters of my filament-spools, I redesigned my simple-clip-together Spool-Roller. Here's the result.

Just print two pieces of the "Plate"-Parts and one Base, add 12 608-Bearings (3 on each X-pin) and snap together.

It works great with many Spool-Sizes !

This is an helmet front mount for a GoPro action cam

I use a Ty-rap to secure it to the helmet

for the knob and nut, I prefer to use M4 instead of the original M5 (It works the same, save weight and the captive nut has more space around)

Printed in ABS with supports enabled and a M4 captive nut inside the fast release attachment

3D models of skate helmet and GoPro camera comes from Grabcad
https://grabcad.com/library/skate-helmet
https://grabcad.com/library/gopro-hero-3-hd-camera-with-the-frame
For captive nuts remember to pause the gcode and insert the nuts a better explanation how to can be found in some of my previous things, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:587659 as an example

author: SpaceRamen

description.text: Gray matter segmented from a head MRI.
Support needed.

Holder for set of 7 nut drivers with tray for bits and bobs.

The drivers are from Harbor Freight -- holder should fit the metric or SAE nut driver set. Or any screwdrivers that aren't too long.. Shaft holes are about 80mm long, handles about 32mm diameter

Looks like a flower pot or mushroom.
There are four places to put 12mm Nb magnets on the bottom, if you need them. You can also stick it on the wall if put a magnet at the bottom of each nut driver shaft to hold them .

title: Plastic storage bin humidity meter mounting

description.text:
This is a remix of my freestanding panel meter to mount a humidity meter on the INSIDE of my filament plastic storage bins, facing out, so I can see if it's time to recharge the desiccant.

The back has plenty of holes for airflow. Mounts the display at an angle facing upwards for better visibility of the LCD through the plastic.

You can get the humidity panel meters from any of the china sources (aliexpress, DX, etc) for under $2each.

You can mount it with flexible glue or use the two screw holes.

The sides slope upwards so you can print without supports and also to make it a little less likely to catch on things inside the bin.

A base object to use in constructing a hexagonal oriented surface. The basic idea is to allow quick layout of arbitrary (hex-based) floor plans with a provision for walls and other objects. This is primarily useful for roleplaying games that use hex grids as the basis for combat. The corner holes allow the secure placement of walls or other fixtures.

The STL files are just included for completeness as I've never gotten them to print. Because the item was developed in stages I've left some of the early files up as they might make a better basis for another effort.  
There are two basic variations: plain meshes and ones that have had a fillet applied. The fillet helps with removal from the build plate and fitting during use. The mk6a is the current model with a fillet and, most importantly, is correctly sized so it can just be loaded and printed, the mk3 is a plain mesh. Differences between the mk3 and mk5 include the corner holes and improved interlock.  
Printed in PLA on a replicator2, default medium with Y dimension set to 32mm (just slightly more than one inch hexes). A print of two took 28m, a print of twelve took 73m.

comments.text: These could be sized for a custom made set of hexes for a "Settlers of Cataan" game.

Here is a small wooly sheep.  
It was created with 123D Catch from a ceramic garden ornament.  The ornament contains reflective additions and is white and shiny - see image.  It was dulled with fine chocolate powder to aid 123D Catch.

The orginal sheep is 20 cm wide, 35 cm long, and 30 cm high.  Wooly_sheep.stl is 33 mm wide, 57 mm long and 48 mm high, or an approximately  1/6 scale version.  
It can be printed directly on the build platform.  I used 5% infill and 2 shells and it printed in about 75 minutes.  The ears overhang slightly but the print was fine.

3Dprint.com did a story on this "thing" here: http://3dprint.com/87878/3d-printed-plinko/

So candy is always awesome, but what makes candy better? Plinko of course! Here is a video of it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ux6LNk0vZ9I

This is a fully 3D printed Plinko style candy dispenser that is a remix of one of my earlier designs (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:663378). Ever since I created the original version, I was wanting to create a Plinko style machine, and this is what I came up with. While I was in the middle of the design process, I stumbled upon this video on Youtube by Steve Ramsey (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CDAbVpCc4dk). He posts many of his woodworking projects for free, so be sure to check some of his stuff out!

I designed this to use spherical candy that is roughly 0.5" in diameter. So Gobstoppers and small gumballs work perfectly (although I'm sure other candy will work as well).

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Print the following files:

  • (2) PlinkoControlKnob.stl
  • (1) PlinkoShaft.stl
  • (1) CandyPlinko.stl

For the top:
If you would like a "fancy" top like the one shown in the pictures print the PlinkoTop_WithGroove.stl and PlinkoDecoration_V2.stl. The Plinko decoration while will snap into the groove. You may want to add some super glue for good measure. If you would like to keep it simple, then just print the PlinkoTop.stl

Construction:

  1. After you have created your parts you will need to cut out a piece of plexi-glass or glass. I used a .100" (or 2.5mm) thick piece of plexi-glass cut at 5.25" x 6.75". Your cut glass should slide in nicely!
  2. Glue one of your control knobs to the shaft and insert it onto the hole of the Plinko base. After that, glue on the other control knob. Make sure to NOT glue all three parts together at once because it will not fit in the hole!
  3. Fill your Plinko machine with your desired candy (I used gobstoppers)
  4. Add your top and enjoy!

description.text:
Ideal for holding ruler, vernier caliper, scissors, marker, screwdrivers, pens and a multitool. Contains:
1 x 35 mm (with dividers)
1 x 35 mm
1 x 30 mm
1 x 15 mm
5 x 13 mm
2 x 8 mm
Total size is 134 x 135 x 83 mm
Total Volume 214 cm3

I wanted to make a camera mount that would allow me to get shots from above and behind me as I fished from my kayak, so I made this using a $5 extendable paint pole from Lowe's. It uses the 5 threads per inch thread pattern from halley's model. It screws on tightly to the paint pole and is held together with 1/4" x 20 bolts and lock nuts. The camera can pan and tilt and maintains its angle due to the use of a rubber washer that grips the striations in the parts nicely.

This should work with any camera that uses the standard 1/4-20 mounting screw, but it could easily be adapted for use with other cameras.

Hardware needed
1 1/4-20 x 1.5" bolt
2 1/4-20 x 1" bolt
1 1/4x1/2x1/16" rubber washer
3 1/4-20 lock nuts
4 1/4" washers

Print out all three pieces. No supports are needed. I printed them at a layer height of 0.3mm and an infill of 15%. This seems plenty strong enough, but if you are expecting more stress from a larger camera or impact, you could always print them with a higher infill.

  1. Attach the fork to the screw base with a 1x1/4-20 bolt with a washer between the fork and the screw base and also between the screw base and the lock nut. This should allow the fork to turn without the nut loosening.
  2. Attach the camera plate to the fork with a 1x1.5-20 bolt with a lock nut with a 1/4x1/2x1/16" rubber washer between one side of the fork and the camera base . This allows you to change the angle of the camera, but still holds it very secure.
  3. Put a 1/4-20 bolt up through the camera plate and secure it with a lock washer. Screw the camera onto the bolt and adjust the bolt to the desired rotation.
  4. Screw the assembly onto a paint pole, broom handle, mop handle, etc. with a thread count of 5 per inch.

Like my previously uploaded Proton Pack Parts I created these models to avoid buying expensive and rare movie prop replica parts for my Proton Pack Particle Thrower. This thing includes nearly all the odds and ends you need to create a Particle Thrower from scratch. I've also included an untested "Gun Box" enclosure. This makes up the main body of the Particle Thrower. I ended up buying mine from eBay when I built my pack due to time and build platform limitations. In addition to the cost saving related to printing the enclosure I bet with some modifications you could include mounting points for all of the necessary electronics. I added a green laser module (pictured above) that fires when the Thrower is activated and getting it lined up was a pain! A pre-printed laser mount would be pretty awesome. MANY more photos are available on Flickr here: https://www.flickr.com/photos/thenewhobbyist/sets/72157633624946837/ Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lt2DhqRzRVA
Below is a list of all the parts I've included. To see what they are and where they go I recommend checking out Sean Bishop's plans. Particle Thrower Parts List:

• pt_BottomRail - Bottom Rail
  • pt_ClippardValve - Generic Clippard Valve
  • pt_Grip - Grips
  • pt_GunBox - Full Gun Box (slightly experimental)
  • pt_Heatsink - Heatsink
  • pt_InstrumentBar - Instrument Bar
  • pt_PVCCaps - 1" PVC End Caps, used in multiple places
  • pt_ThrowerKnobs - Knobs for Gun Box
  • pt_ThrowerMount - Mount for Particle Thrower
  • pt_TriggerBox - Trigger Box

description.text:
This is a 2-part enclosure for the JDSLabs CmoyBB Headphone Amplifier kit. It ends up being slightly taller, but a bit shorter, than an Altoids tin, and with proper ABS smoothing it'll look pretty sweet.

I made this partially just to do it, but mostly because I'm too lazy to buy a hole punch and punch holes in an altoids tin. The two halves are a little loose right now; I plan on going back and fixing this up later when I have time. the scad is NOT parametric, so I didn't give this the customizer tag, and could use a little polish otherwise, but if you dive in most things should be self explanatory.

printed at .3mm with 20% infill, but it should be pretty resilient as far as settings go. Enabling support for the tabs is recommended but not required. After the part is printed, slip the power port in sideways first and then the PCB should easily settle into place after that.

remixed_from.author: 0110-M-P
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more

description.text:
This is a case for a SainSmart 4-channel relay module that I have wired to my raspberry pi and controlled through Octoprint.

I designed the case with the following features in mind:

  • Small form factor
  • Access holes for JD-VCC pins as well as the line-in pins
  • Access holes for the screw terminal
  • Tube/holes for easy viewing of the status LED's

The style of the case was based upon this Raspberry Pi case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740).

This was optimized for a 0.4mm nozzle. The included pictures were printed in PLA with a 0.25 layer height. No support needed. The top cover STL needs to be flipped over and printed upside down.

The screw holes are sized for M3 screws. To secure the board to the base I used M3 x 10 mm screws, however shorter screws are necessary. I used a hex nut as as spacer to make the 10 mm screw work (I didn't have anything shorter). The cover can be secured with M3 x 16mm or 12mm screws.

title: Multirotor Motor Mount, 19mm x 16mm mounting holes

description.text:
Rather than wait on replacement shipping for replacement acryllic mounts that break to easily, I decided to create my own for printing. It is designed to slip on the end of 1/4in aluminum or carbon fiber, and has mounting holes spaced at 19mm and 16 mm to mount the motor.
Screw holes are sized for M3 screws.
Part was designed in Solidworks, and then repaired using NetFabb to ensure printability.

author: CJGrimm

description.text:
This Google Cardboard compatible viewer is capable of supporting of phones up to 4.8 inches in size and is a perfect fit for a Samsung S3 with a case; 5.0 should still be doable.

It's made up of multiple parts for easy modification and relies on M3 bolts to keep it all together. I do suggest adding some padding to keep it all nice and comfortable if you're going to use a strap.

This current version features 38mm lenses which I "borrowed" from my old Oculus Rift DK1 but I'll make a version for use with the official Cardboard sized lenses as soon as it arrives.

ADDITION: Now includes an improved visor. It uses almost double the amount of plastic but allows for easy adding of padding and has a top strap holder.

12x 16mm M3 bolts
1x 10 mm M3 bolt
2x 38mm lenses with a focal length of 38.5-40mm

description.text:
The Breadboard Spring Vise makes it easy to hold circuit boards of various sizes in place next to your breadboard. It has no trouble accommodating larger, full-size Arduino Uno or Leonardo boards, and it has no trouble grabbing onto a diminutive ESP-01 ESP8266 board.

The Raspberry Pi fits in the jaws, and it stays in place quite well, but the micro USB and HDMI ports prevent the outside of the board from landing correctly in the grooves of the jaw. The "version 3" jaws are narrow enough at the top to allow a USB cable to be plugged into the Pi.

  • Breadboard Spring Vise at Tindie
  • Breadboard Spring Vise at patshead.com
  • Breadboard Spring Vise at Github
  • Breadboard Spring Vise at YouTube

You should also check out the Simple Component Box for Breadboard Spring Vise!

I am using #32 rubber bands.

comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: The two sides are identical.  They're both generated from the same OpenSCAD function.  One vise base is just shifted over a breadboard + wall thickness.  There are two walls down the center that overlap.  They should be overlapping perfectly.

comments.text: I used cura.  I hope it's not a problem with my printer.  I try to fit the board in and it really bends the plastic and won't quite seat.  Pefrectly fine on the other side.. fits like the single wide one did.
comments.author: patshead

comments.text: I'm sure your printer is just fine.  I don't know if you're printing with PLA or ABS.  I've always used ABS.  It has a lot of advantages for me over PLA, but it has one major flaw.  It shrinks a little as it cools, and contracting by almost 0.3mm on a print that size doesn't seem entirely out of the question.  On a large print, it is possible one side is cooling faster than the other.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: I'm using PLA.  A 1 kg roll of red Excelevan I got from ebay for $9.99 with free shipping :)
comments.author: patshead

comments.text: Would it be possible to have another version of that double-wide where there is no center bar.  i.e. you fit the two breadboards together with their dovetails then place both of them, as one unit, in the vise.  Don't know if this would present any problems or not.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: Let me know if you change your mind. Creating a double width base without the center wall is as easy as doubling one variable in the source.  I wouldn't know how snug the fit would be without a test print, though.  It may very well need to be a few tenths of a mm wider.

Fvtvtor v1 (selfmade)

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 µm

solid

Originally printed from PLA. Should work with any material though.
You might want to upscale the screw a bit before printing to get a smooth fit (shit_stutzen_zu-pumpe schraube.stl).

Assembly
  • Cut a hole into the sidewall of your pool
  • Attach some suitable glue to the flat areas of the parts
  • Stick "shit_stutzen_zu-pumpe innen.stl" into the hole (from the inside of the pool)
  • Attach "shit_stutzen_zu-pumpe aussen.stl"
  • Put on the screw
  • Attach your hosepipe

description.text:
25mm（thickness 11mm） Fan shroud for J-Head hotend.
Aug.8, updated to v2: If it is easy to remove shroud from heat sink, use v2.

One of the key for master sharpening is a perfect constant blade angle . This tool holds the knife at a preset perfect cutting angle during sharpening with a stone.
For Knife with blade width 1.5 cm to 6cm, thickness 1.5mm to 3mm
Default Sharpening angle 20 degree, i.e. 40 degree both sides.
You need a cheap 8 inches long ceramic or carbide sharpening stone. Tape one end to reduce friction.

Print :
PLA
Rotate 90 degree on its side to print
Speed 60
Shell 1.2mm, Fill 15%

Usage:
overhange the knife blade edge 1 to 2mm beyond the edge of the sharpener holder

description.text:
Perfect for a desk or window-sill, this planter allows your herbs and greenery to continually sip water from a reservoir in the bottom rather than being stressed by wet-dry cycles over time.

The inner sleeve will lift right out of the device easily, and the stylish integrated spout allows you to either add water as needed, check the level any time, or pour out old water for cleaning.

I've tried to take advantage of all of the production benefits offered by 3D printing, using generous curves and filets where possible, things that would be prohibitively expensive to achieve on a clay or metal planter produced by traditional means.

I'm dedicating this part to public domain, make any use of it you wish, including commercial sales :)

Inspired by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:903411

Edit: nadams810 has posted a variant which he found more printable: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:981004

Edit2: Made the water holes half as big, .050".

author: Jojumy

description.text:
This is the third test version of an unbreakable tube. The tube is highly resistant to axial pressure. Accidental radial forces will angle tube's element, but will not break the tube. The string inside the tube will build up a tension similar to "prestressed concrete". Angled tube elements will flip back to their origin, if you use an elastic string. Use a strong string/wire to make the tube manual unbreakable.
Some results so far:
  • Longer tube elements are less stable.
  • Bending the tube very often will damage the edges of the tube elements. Check the red arrows in one of the pictures.
  • The string looses tension after a bending due to less friction of the angled parts.
    • Things to do:
  • design tube elements with a constricted opening on both sides
  • design a rounded, more durable shape
  • find another tightening mechanism
    • Update to V3 (improved elements, OpenSCAD optimization)

Print at least one of each part and several of the tube elements. Then assemble it with a strong string. Make a knot at the open end. Rotate the upper part of the assembled tube clock wise, to increase the tension. The two strings inside the tube will twist by this rotation. Build up enough tension. Then try to bend the tube.

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.

This booster uses an optical link, and requires no modification of the TV-B-Gone itself. Just insert the TV-B-Gone into the booster. The booster reads the output from the TV-B-Gone using an LTR3208E phototransistor and switches the same signal to 19 TSAL7200 60mW IR diodes, using a simple TIP122 transistor. The end result is that you boost the output power from the TV-B-Gone to 1140 mW (external 9-12V battery pack required). For added awesomeness, I have created a 3D-printed 50s ray gun enclosure to hold the booster and TV-B-Gone :) Bill of materials:
19 x TSAL7200 IR diodes
19 x 33 ohm resistors
1 x LTR3208E IR phototransistor (make sure it points directly towards the emitter on the TV-B-Gone
1 x 1kohm resistor
1 x TIP122 transistor All of the components can be swapped with equivalent versions, but you have to make sure the emitter and receiver operate on the correct wavelength (940 nm)

comments.text: You DO realize this could easily be fixed with a petition, instead of dangling something awesome RIGHT in our face and saying "nope, you're not allowed to use this because i'm going to attempt to rant about a rulechange in a way that does absolutely nothing!"
comments.author: ConnorYoung

comments.text: I love my tv-b-gone, but I might have to give it a make over now.  ha ha ha...
comments.author: DaGroundZero

comments.text: I did something similar when I was a kid, I took a learning universal remote and added some scrounge IR LEDs to the front on some long wires, I then added them to a crude parabolic reflector I attached to the end of a huge foil lined cardboard tube. I think it was used for rolls of carpet.  replaced the AA batteries with wires going to C cells. Long story short I had a learning remote bazooka I could control any TV I had a line of sight to from hundreds of feet away. I would change channels and volume while my neighbors tried to watch, I would turn on TVs at three AM and crank up the volume on horror movies...I pity my old neighbors. I'm going to make a custom case/reflector/amplifier or the guts of a learning remote. I hope you don't mind if I mash up some of your parts to do it. Just waiting on a digital caliper I ordered. I saw a file for a proper parabolic reflector on here too.
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: I used to buy a lot of stuff from Mouser, DigiKey, Farnell and RS Components, but now I usually get all my components from eBay (much cheaper for me, since I am based in Norway (== import tax / shipping hell :)).
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: Do you have a photograph of how the emitter is wired up? If I can see it I can do it but the diagram is not how I think.
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: Forgot to answer one of your questions. Yes, in theory, you can desolder the IR-diode from the TV-B-Gone, and use this signal to drive a transistor that in turn drives a potentially huge array of IR diodes. You should be able to find instructables on how to do this (The downside is that you might break the TV-B-Gone if you do something wrong) I did something similar some time ago (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y2EbQ2U2tTk)http://www.youtube.com/watch?v... (ps. looks like I got the specs wrong in the youtube video. They are rated at minimum 40 mW / typical 60 mW but you can drive them to 200mW if you are feeling brave :))
comments.author: Peterthinks

comments.text: Wire a 33 ohm resistor to the longest leg of each TSAL7200. Insert all the diodes and connect the shortest legs in parallel (I connected these almost like a LED-cube, where one leg connects to the next). Wire these to the collector of the TIP122. Wire the resistor ends in parallel and hook these up to the 5V output of the 7805 voltage regulator. PS. If you are unsure of the polarity of the IR diodes, you can hook one up directly to a CR2450 (or similar 3V button cell) and look at the output with a digital camera (this won't work with an iphone, but many digital cameras have IR-filters that will let some of this through. You will see a weak light when looking at the diode in the camera)

but then i thought, i have a 3d printer. and then only a few hours later i came up with the tactical eating apparatus, this slim food safe multi tool is great to take with you wherever you go, it has an easy clip to make sure you don't loose track of it and a slim stylish design.

title: Large Stephen Colbert Head-Bre Pettis Interview-3D Printing-Support Kickstarter Project to Launch Soon!

description.text: The rumors are true.  Stephen Colbert's head has gotten very big ;-)...so big that I hollowed it out and you can wear it.  That's right, this is your very own wearable Stephen Colbert head so you to can be Stephen Colbert. No I'm not going Silence of the Lambs on y'all, it's printed in nylon.  Its a tight fit in my large frame laser sintering machine...the material alone would cost thousands of dollars, but I want to build one so bad in one piece!  Ah ha, maybe I can finance the building of it by gathering donations on Kickstarter?  I have set up a build with 700 1/12 scale versions that will fit around the full scale head and be the reward for donating!

You can print small pieces on your Thing-o-matic and glue them together to make your very own large head, or shrink the file down and print your own scale version.  If you don't have access to a printer or want to support the project, pledge $25 on Kickstarter and get your very own 1/12 scale souvenier head in laser sintered nylon.

title: A mountable Qi Charging Dock for Galaxy Note 4

description.text:
Update: I used this in my car with Note 5 for a month, it works fine but wobbly, so you might wanna scale it a percent or two.

The last of the Galaxy Note series that has SD expansion slot and removable battery. This is designed for Galaxy Note 4, T-mobile version, with Samsung's OEM wireless charging cover.

The charging puck is a very popular inexpensive puck, PowerBot PB1020 and many more branding of the same puck.

Bolt pattern is standard AMPS, 30mm by 38mm but this one is diagonal, using RAM mount diamond base plate, and #6 bolts.

It was tweaked to fit very nicely, while easy to just drop it in. No more fiddling to plug in cables.

All buttons are completely exposed, especially the two buttons on the bottom.

Since it's a standard mount pattern, you can mount it on many things that are compatible.

Some supports are needed, you can print upright.

I had a lot of Issues with the original Renkforce RF-1000 Filament feeding tube, because it took a lot of force to move it through.
A lot of people usually have a shelf or mount a stick to the wall to hang their spools in for easy acces and loading. Unfortunately I can't mount anything to the wall where I work, so I thought: why not attach it to the printer?
So this is what I came up with. It's a total of 4 pieces (2 pieces are Identical). 2 Pieces (the mounts) get screwed on to the Renkforce Printer and the other 2 pieces (holders) just get stuck into the mount. Now you just need a broomstick and you can load and store Filament above the printer without having to worry about it getting stuck in the feeding tube. The holders even feature a possibility to attach Zip lock ties on each side. Also the holders can easily be removed for transport of the printer.
UPDATE: If the Print bed of your printer is not large enough you have to print the short holder and extension file

There are a total of 4 Pieces (2 are identical).
2 Pieces (the mounts) get screwed on to the the existing screws of the printer. Note: you will need longer M4 screws than the original ones!.
There are two different mounts. Left and right. Print those at 0.2 or 0.3mm with an Infill of at least 50%, 2 Shells and Supports. You have to print the holder two times with the same options as the mounts.
Now just screw the Mounts onto each side of the printer and stick the holders in (should hold tightly together without glue) with the Zip lock attachment either facing inward or outwards. Now all you need is a broomstick (Preferably wood) with a diameter of max. 28 mm.
One last tip: Keep a small section of the original feeding tube (4-6 cm).
If you have Issues, because your Printbed is to small you just have to print the short holder and extension file 2 times to get the full length of the holder

description.text: Minnie Maus Scan

Last summer I had the opportunity to meet a number of talented computer science teachers at a workshop for CS50AP in Redmond. During the discussion on binary someone mentioned a lesson they do using coins with binary values as a way to begin teaching the concept. Students are only given one of each coin and are told they will be going to a candy store and must pay in exact change. They quickly realize that no matter what the price (up to a maximum) they can always pay in exact change.

I decided I needed a set to use with my own students. Although, I used them slightly differently. In my scenario they were tokens for a new transit system going in. Just like on a city bus riders must pay in exact change and the price of a ride depends on a variety of factors, but ranges from $0.01 to $2.50. The question would is, "What combination of tokens you would need to guarantee you could take any ride?" I printed three or four sets and mixed them together for my students. Depending on your class size you may need more.

Printer:

i3 Duplicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

I made these coins in Tinkered. Total time to create was just a few minutes. You can edit them there or even break them into individual stl's if needed.

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fgJYkHROcQ0-binary-coins

The design is really very simple:

  • Drag in a cylinder and make it the size you want your coin to be
  • Add a cylinder hole a bit smaller than the first. Lift it off the build plane until it only cuts 1 mm into your coin
  • Use the Text Shape Generator to create your numbers. Size appropriately and place on your coin.

These coins are intended to help introduce the idea of binary numbers. Most students only familiar with our normal base 10 numbering system and it is often helpful to have physical objects on hand to help students build the idea of other numbering systems. Objectives:
  • Students will recognize that all the tokens provided double in size
  • Students will be able to explain how any number from 1 to 255 can be created using only a single set of these tokens
  • Students will begin building a mental model for a base 2 numbering system
    • Audiences:
  • This activity is intended for students being taught abstraction as a computational thinking
    • Subjects:
  • Math
  • Computer Science
    • Skills Learned (Standards):
  • Computational Thinking Practice - Abstraction
  • Computational Thinking Practice - Analyzing Problems and Artifacts

• Provide the prompt below and multiple sets of tokens:
    A new tech startup, Janus Ride, has announced they will use self driving electric cars to take you from any address in town to any other address in town. You will be charged based on the precise distance and projected travel time. Due to inherent efficiencies and public subsidies the price of a ride will vary from an absurdly low $0.01 to a still amazingly low $2.50. The rider must pay in exact change only using official Janus Ride tokens. Tokens come in values of $1.28, $0.64, $0.32, $0.16, $0.08, $0.04, $0.02, and $0.01.
  • Have students propose trips form school to various locations around town and give them projected costs. These are not very critical, just make up any price up to $2.50. Ask students to provide exact change for multiple different destinations.
  • Once they have done a few, ask student groups to determine what is the best combination of tokens to have that would allow them to take any ride.
  • Have groups share in whole class discussion. Have students contrast this with traditional money. What combination of coins would they need? Is this more or less efficient?
    • Duration:
    Depending on your students, this activity can take 15 to 30 minutes. Preparation:
    You should have multiple sets of tokens available. Students require no prior knowledge or preparation.
Binary Numbers - Computers Unplugged - There are lots of resources for helping teach students about binary numbers here.

P.S. Don't forget about a small screw on a big metal corner, it is twirled with 1mm a washer, as on the picture, its role in alignment of geometry when braking that brakes were parallel to a brake disk.
tross_holder is a holder of a brake braid from below of the scooter.
120mm diskbrake you can find on aliexpress;)

Titanic
A Carriage that enables you to mount an E3D hotend (or similar 16mm grove mount hotend) to a Tantillus printer

File names should be fairly self explanatory. The anti warp version has a 2mm tall circle around it to stop the piece from warping when printed This will need to be cut off before use. It uses 2 x M3 nuts and grubscrews to hold the hot end (I cut the heads off M3 x10mm machine screws and slotted them with a dremel to make the Grubscrews) the linear bearings are a push fit. My copy has been in use for ~6 months now I printed in PLA and have had no problems with it melting due to the proximity of the hotend and I regularly print in nylon.

There is a commented out passage in the open scad file that enables the anti warp circle, just uncomment it.

Taking apart and assembling this model requires a screwdriver. One day you arrive at your favorite flying spot just to find out you forgot your screwdriver and can't fly your VisionAire.
I designed this little part that holds the screws in place and enables assembly without any tools.

Also check out my other thing for this airplane, together they make assembly at the field a breeze.

I printed it in white ABS, standing up on its head. In my print, the hole for the screw is just a bit too small. To attach the screw heat it until it will just melt the ABS and press into this holder making sure its straight. After cooling it should fit securely and not fall out. Inside the cavity for the screw heat is some extra plastic that will flow into the X of the screw giving extra grip.
